QUESTIONS ON MINISTERIAL STATEMENT
(Announcement by Mr Speaker)


     Mr Speaker: Whenever a ministerial statement is made in this House, it has been the practice for the Chair to permit hon. Members to raise elucidatory questions on the statement.

    However, in a recent ministerial statement, some of the questions asked of the Hon. Minister seemed to go beyond the confines permitted. I would like to take this opportunity to briefly clarify the procedure.

    Questions on a ministerial statement must be confined solely to the contents of the statement. They should not be prefaced with unnecessary statements or be framed in such a way or manner as to invite or to provoke a debate. Debate on a ministerial statement is irregular. If any hon. Member feels that only a debate would satiate his mind on the issues in the ministerial statement, there are avenues open to him, one of which is to file a substantive motion.

    Finally, I would like to make it clear that the rules governing the contents of Questions to Ministers are generally applicable.

ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PRESIDENT OF THE REPUBLIC OF SINGAPORE
(Executive powers)


    1. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence whether he will elaborate on his statement made at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy that the government proposes to amend the Constitution to enable a future President to share powers with the Prime Minister.

     The First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence (Mr Goh Chok Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Anson has not read the text of my speech at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy carefully. I did not say that the Constitution would be amended "to enable a future President to share powers with the Prime Minister". Those were the words of the Straits Times journalist who had paraphrased my speech.

    What I said was:

    'The President will be vested with veto powers in certain areas. He will not have the powers of President Reagan. The Prime Minister will remain the Chief Executive of the country. But in areas where the President is vested with veto powers, the Prime Minister has to have his concurrence. The areas which we have in mind relate to the use of the country's financial reserves. These reserves, including those accumulated

Column: 663

by previous governments from the same party, cannot be freely spent without the President's agreement. The President, for example, may withhold his consent if the Cabinet proposes to spend the reserves on wasteful programmes or projects. This way, we have an additional safeguard against our financial reserves being squandered by a potentially profligate government.'

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, a supplementary question for the First Deputy Prime Minister. But, first of all, could I ask him whether he does not think it improper, or perhaps uncalled for, to take issue with me on what is reported in his own paper, the Straits Times? I never saw any correction of this report from the First Deputy Prime Minister. But I will let that pass.

    May I ask the First Deputy Prime Minister, first of all, was there any reason why he went to the other side of the world to speak on a matter that concerns the people of Singapore primarily, without first discussing the proposals with the people of Singapore?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I thought the Member for Anson has jumped up to apologize to me for having not read my speech carefully. Instead he has taken issue with the Straits Times and me for not having corrected the wrong reporting. The Member for Anson should have read my speech which was also published in the same issue of the Straits Times. My speech was also telecast. So he owes me an apology rather than the other way round.

    Why did I go to Boston to make a speech on a matter which concerns Singaporeans? The Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy organizes conferences on ASEAN. Last year it was a conference on Singapore, the year before it was on Indonesia. It was a seminar wherein other speakers were also invited. I thought the main interest of the audience would be the political future of Singapore and I therefore delivered a speech on a matter which I believe was of great interest to the audience.

    Is there anything wrong with a Minister making a speech which concerns Singaporeans in a country outside Singapore? The Member for Anson himself went to Penang to talk on human rights, and he

Column: 664

was in Jakarta to talk about the plight of the foreign workers in Singapore. Is he not contradicting himself when he asked me that question?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the First Deputy Prime Minister if he is not aware of the distinction between my speaking in Jakarta or in Penang and the First Deputy Prime Minister speaking to foreigners about how we propose to govern ourselves in the future, without the matter first having been discussed with the people? I would respectfully suggest to the Minister that there is a distinction. The First Deputy Prime Minister himself this morning says that he told the Americans that there were certain -

     Mr Speaker: I thought you are asking a supplementary question, Mr Jeyaretnam. But you are making a speech.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I was just saying that the First Deputy Prime Minister mentioned "areas". "Areas" is a plural word. Would the First Deputy Prime Minister define the areas in which it is proposed that the President should have veto powers? Does he not realize that the Prime Minister, speaking on this sometime last year, or was it the year before, confined it to purely the use of foreign reserves? Did the First Deputy Prime Minister enlarge these areas before the Americans?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, first the question of distinction between the Member for Anson speaking to a foreign audience and the First Deputy Prime Minister speaking to an American audience. The distinction is this. He has double standards. I do not have double standards. But that is not the important point of the debate this morning.

    I referred to areas related to financial reserves. I did not go beyond what the Prime Minister has said on this issue in Singapore. We are concerned with the protection of financial reserves. How we protect these financial reserves is a question that is being studied by the Auditor-General, Accountant-General and the Permanent Secretaries who have to refine the plan to make it workable. Hence I used the words "areas related to financial reserves". The matter has been discussed

Column: 665

in Singapore. I did not raise anything new in Boston. I was merely projecting ourselves into the future for the Americans who have an interest in the future of Singapore. I did not go into areas which the Member for Anson, in his own mind, thought I had gone into.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Is the First Deputy Prime Minister in a position now to define these areas? That is what I am asking.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Anson is long on questions and short on memory. The matter was discussed sometime last year when he questioned the Prime Minister on this issue. The Prime Minister then said that it would take about two years for the details to be refined into a workable proposal to be formulated in a White Paper and submitted to the House. So please wait. It will take about two years from last year.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Could the First Deputy Prime Minister tell us whether this proposal will first be published in a White Paper and then thrown open to the people of Singapore for discussion?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I just said that the Member for Anson is very long on questions and very short on memory. The Prime Minister has said last year, and I repeat, that the proposal will be published as a White Paper and submitted to Parliament and, of course, Parliament will discuss this.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: The question is whether it will be thrown to the public for discussion. That is my question: whether the public will be invited, whether there would be public meetings and discussions on this matter?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, when the proposal is published as a White Paper, the public is welcomed to discuss it and the Members of Parliament from both sides of the House can convene public meetings to discuss the paper.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Mr Speaker, Sir, the First Deputy Prime Minister suggests the changes which, in my mind, are very drastic. In other words, if you give veto powers to the President -

Column: 666



     Mr Speaker: Where is your supplementary question, Mr Chiam?

     Mr Chiam See Tong: - we are virtually taking away the supremacy of Parliament, changing the system as we know it today and which has served us so well for the last 25 years. My question is: Since this is going to be a very serious matter, will the Government put it to the people of Singapore, maybe in the form of a referendum, before these changes are made?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am afraid the Member for Potong Pasir shares with the Member for Anson in not recalling a matter which was debated here last year. The answer given last year was that a referendum is very expensive but if the need for a referendum is there and the Members for Potong Pasir and Anson press for it and we feel that there is a need for it, it will be put to the people.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: May I inform the First Deputy Prime Minister that he is quite right in what the Prime Minister said: that they would consider it. But the question this morning is: Will you go to the people on a referendum? We are asking for a referendum. There is no question of considering it. You said you will go to the people on a referendum if there is a demand for it, and I say we are asking for it.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Contain your patience. When the proposal is published in the form of a White Paper and should the Member for Anson ask for it at that time, supported by the Member for Potong Pasir -

     Mr Jeyaretnam: We will get it.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: - we will consider it very seriously.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, as regards costs of the referendum, how much will that be - $1 million, $2 million? The Government has thrown away $18 million last December. Is that just to boost up the sagging image of the PAP?

     Mr Speaker: Mr Jeyaretnam, your second question.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Is a referendum not as important as an exhibition?

     Mr Speaker: You are asking a question that is not indicated in the Question.

Column: 667



     Mr Chiam See Tong: Yes, all right. We will get the First Deputy Prime Minister to speak out loud and clear whether or not there will be a referendum. We have been asked to give straight answers. But we hope the Government will now give straight answers.

     Mr Speaker: Mr Jeyaretnam, your second question.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I have another supplementary question, Mr Speaker, Sir.

     Mr Speaker: All right.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Before I dispose of this question, may I ask the First Deputy Prime Minister whether the American businessmen or whoever attended this lecture asked for an assurance that the PAP Government would continue to rule Singapore before they would continue to invest in Singapore?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, before I answer the question, on the supplementary question phrased in the form of a long speech by the Member for Potong Pasir, there will be a referendum if the people feel the need for a referendum.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Yes or no?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Did the American investors ask for an assurance that the PAP would be in power before they would invest. They did not ask for an assurance in that particular manner.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: In what manner did they ask?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: But they were very reassured that we are taking steps to ensure that there will be a stable government in Singapore in the 1990s.

PENALTY ON PARKING WARDEN MR BALRAJOO


    2. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for National Development why a penalty of $20 was imposed on Parking Enforcement Officer Mr. Balrajoo s/o Ragavan for reporting that motor vehicle EU 3803K had been found parked at Pine Grove Car Park on the 22nd of August 1985 at 1.31 a.m. without displaying any parking label authorizing the parking of the vehicle in the car park.

Column: 668



     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): Mr Speaker, Sir, a penalty of $20 was imposed on Balrajoo s/o Ragavan by the HDB for his negligence in wrongly issuing a parking offence notice. This was done under HDB's disciplinary rules as provided in its Instruction Manual for parking wardens. These rules have been formulated to ensure that members of the public are not inconvenienced through negligence or abuse of authority by parking wardens. Most of HDB parking wardens are, however, performing well. In the last 12 months, there were only four other cases where similar penalties had to be imposed on parking wardens.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Would the Minister, first of all, confirm that this member of the public is also a Member of this House? And, secondly, would the Minister say whether any inquiry was held and the officer in question informed of the evidence against him before the penalty of $20 was slapped on him?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, on the first supplementary question, the answer is yes. On the second supplementary question, the penalty has been imposed in accordance with the HDB rules governing its staff.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I sometimes despair of Ministers answering the questions put to them. Will the Minister answer the question: was there any inquiry conducted? Was the statement of the Member of Parliament about whether he had displayed any parking label on the car brought to the notice of this officer?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is not necessary under the HDB rules to conduct an inquiry and call the Member of Parliament to be present. But HDB officers in charge of this case have followed the HDB rules governing its staff and have imposed the penalty.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Are we to understand from the Minister that the HDB is an authority unto itself that it can punish anybody without even telling him what the offence is, what the evidence against him is, and without hearing him?

Column: 669



     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, as far as HDB staff are concerned, the disciplinary action against the staff is clearly laid down in the HDB's administrative rules, and its staff is following these rules. The action taken against its staff is in accordance with these rules.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Would the Minister please disclose the rule or regulation under which this penalty was imposed?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the Member for Anson does not seem to listen to my answer. I have stated in my answer quite clearly that this penalty was imposed under the HDB disciplinary rules, as provided in its Instruction Manual for parking wardens. I can send him a set of the Instruction Manual on the rules governing parking wardens.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Does the Minister not understand my question? Has he not realized that I am not asking him to send me the Instruction Manual? I was asking him to read to me the specific rule which provides for the HDB to slap on a penalty of $20 on an alleged negligence, or otherwise, of an officer.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, if the Member for Anson is interested in this matter, I will send him the rules. And when he reads the rules, then he will understand why the penalty has been imposed.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I want it now.

     Mr Speaker: Let's save time. Send him the rules, Mr Teh.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, supplementary question. May I ask the Minister how many cases similar to the one mentioned here where the -

     Mr Speaker: It has just been mentioned.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: - where the matter was brought under this disciplinary rule, where a fine was imposed on a warden or on any other persons? Were there other similar cases?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, again, the Member for Potong Pasir does not seem to listen to my answer. I have stated here quite clearly that "most of the HDB parking wardens are, however, performing well." That means, they are per-

Column: 670

forming well. And in the last 12 months, there were only four other cases where similar penalties had to be imposed on the parking wardens. You must understand that HDB is the largest car parking authority and HDB controls more than 200,000 car park lots. The warden has to look after, patrol and ensure that parking in these more than 200,000 car park lots is orderly. A large number of HDB wardens are performing this duty. And HDB, by and large, has good parking wardens and, therefore, disciplinary action taken against wardens is very rare. And in the last 12 months, there were only four cases where HDB had to impose a penalty on these wardens. I think that both the Members just refuse to listen to my answer.

     Dr Augustine H.H. Tan (Whampoa): Sir, may I ask the Hon. Minister whether there are normal channels of appeal for such cases, and whether the officer in question has made use of or exhausted all the normal channels of appeal without going outside?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, there is a normal channel of appeal, but I understand that the person in question has admitted the offence and has paid up the penalty.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Is the Minister aware that it is not a question of the officer paying the $20? It was deducted from him. Is the Minister not aware that there is a subtle difference between the man paying up $20 and it being compulsorily deducted from his salary?

    The other question is: will the Minister tell us whether these four cases that he referred to related to vehicles of PAP MPs?

    The third question is: would the Minister tell us whether this particular Member has a season parking ticket which he was required to display in his housing estate car park where the car was parked, and whether or not it was displayed at that time?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, in fact, the penalty imposed on the parking warden has been paid by the parking warden. It has been deducted.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Was it deducted?

Column: 671



     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Has been deducted.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Thank you.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: It has been paid by the warden. As I understand it, the warden had asked the senior officer for a deduction of the penalty. And the senior officer in charge of the case even helped the warden. The warden pleaded for a deduction of the penalty, and the senior officer in charge, I think paid $10 on behalf of the warden. So the warden paid only $10. And I was told that subsequently this warden had been advised by someone to return the $10 back to the senior officer.

     An hon. Member: By the Member for Anson!

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: On the second question, this particular car, EU3803K, in fact, is an MP's car and has an MP's car label which entitles him to park in HDB estates. On top of that, he has also purchased a season parking ticket.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: For his own estate?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: For his own estate. In fact, that is not necessary. Any Member of Parliament who has an MP's car parking label does not need to purchase a season ticket. So, in short, this particular car has two labels entitling him to park in the HDB estate; one is the MP's car parking label, the other one is the season ticket. And HDB officers investigating this case were satisfied that the Member of Parliament had displayed the MP's label on his car. In fact, the HDB senior officer had personally checked the car and found that the MP's label was stuck on the windscreen and there was only one mark on that windscreen, and the mark was an old mark, not sort of newly stuck on. So the senior officers investigating the case were satisfied that there was negligence on the part of the car parking warden and, therefore, a penalty was imposed on him.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister has not answered my other question, the second question, whether the four other cases also related to motorcars of PAP MPs. And on the question about the repayment of this $10 that was proferred by the senior officer to this man, may I assure the Minister that I knew about this

Column: 672

long after the man had returned the $10 to this officer. [Laughter] I know you find it very funny. There is no question of this man having been advised by me to return the $10.

     Mr Speaker: Mr Jeyaretnam, will you please sit down. There is no reason for you to make an excuse.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I am not making any excuses. He is giving wrong information.
